roads are pretty selfish. they just require enough intellect to have the foresight to be that selfish. there is absolutely nothing egalitarian about roads. they were literally invented with the sole purpose of making it easier to extract wealth from foreigners. than the secondary benefit of commerce came along. commerce that is only important because people figured out extracting your own populations wealth was easier if you could funnel and than count the value. taxes were incredibly hard to get before roads. its hard to deny how much wealth is going to and from your estate when its weighed or inspected on transit. and now they are here to stay because people need to get to work, they aren't charity their an investment. there's a reason why the army still keeps about 5k railroad personal on the pay roll despite not using them for anything but training. its because priority number 1 is always number one even when being place held by 3, 4 , or 49. the army can literally take over the transport infrastructure at any time. and its not to defend from non existent threats. its to ensure A the taxes come in, or B a new source can be extracted and brought back. which is kinda collective benefit. in the sense it keeps the wheel turning.

But, wheels aren't only useful for locomotion. The potters wheel was hugely important to the formation of civilizations. Those who could throw pots faster, could store more things. If you store a lot of seeds and the crops fail, not only will you be more likely to survive, but you can lend seeds to others, at interest. So the wheel is responsible for usury and the division of society into classes as well.

So, I could envision a stationary aquatic lifeform which uses a wheel to bring food into itself faster than passive feeders. I could also envision it having a way to inject lipids into a chamber between the axel & wheel to keep friction from tearing the organism apart. I think the biggest hinderance is developing an apendage which would evolve into detaching itself from the rest of the organism. Even then, to be sustained the wheel would have to have to consume some of the food it delivers to the main organism. It would also need a way to respire and remain in homeostasis. At this point they might as well be two distinct organisms in symbiosis.

Remember, just because we haven't discovered a thing doesn't mean it lacks existence somewhere in the infinite reaches of the Universe. Moreover, a thing not existing shouldn't be confused for a thing lacking the possibility to exist.

The Bacterial Flagella is the only know fully rotary body part because it's a protein strand that needs no metabolism.  The obvious way for a macroscopic organism to have a wheel is for the wheel to be a symbiotic organism of it's own which grows with the organism and replaces it's treds as they wear down.  Think of say a nautilus shell like animal which is gripped by another and spun, the wheel creature might get the benifit of being fed by the other as well as dispersal to other environments.  A natural environment which featured natural flat hard surfaces woiuld likely be nessary such as a frozen liquid surface or a geologically dead planet where everything has erroded down to a flat plane.  Lastly animals DO make trails, which are just the collective trampling of many passing creatures which each selfeshly move where are the fewest obsticles.

In my opinion, trees are a lot like roads.
Animals travel across them, and live in them, and use them for all sorts of purposes for their own selfishness.
The trees are still selfish, though, since they don't grow tall to allow animals to climb across their branches
A hypothetical organism that grows into flat, sheet-like surfaces stretching long distances with a reason to do so could make a road while still being selfish.
Perhaps this organism is plant-like, but gains energy from kinetic energy rather than the sun. They might have flat, plate-like growths on top of their bodies, which, when pressure is applied, convert that kinetic energy into energy used by the organism
If these organisms grew in large patches with parallel plates, they could simultaneously form a road for other animals while gaining energy from the use of said roads, allowing them to spread and make more of themselves

In Philip Pullman’s fantasy novel The Amber Spyglass, we travel to a world where a species of animal has learnt to use wheels. The Mulefa, as they are known, live in an environment with naturally occurring roads: roads of smooth basalt formed from an ancient volcanic eruption. There are also enormous trees that drop large circular seeds. The quadrupedal Mulefa have a diamond shape skeleton so they have a limb directly at the front and back of their body (and one on each side). So they’ve worked out that they can use their front and hind legs to push a hole in the middle of the seed and hook their feet through, creating effectively a living bicycle that can travel great distances at great speeds across natural roads.

I'm just surprised Micheal didn't mention the issue of torque. If an animal had wheels, especially in the way shown in the thumbnail with one on each locomotive limb AND lived in a flat enough area for them to actually be usable, they would still need some way of applying torque to the wheel while letting the wheel remain freespinning on an axle. One option would be to have an ape like creature, anything with opposable thumbs and at least four limbs would do, with wheels for its lower limbs, it would hypothetically be capable of using it a bit like a wheelchair. Even then though, they would need a fifth limb for balance and support when not at high speed. Overall I think wheels are too complex and too useless to ever functionally develop in the animal kingdom.

Why don't animals have wheel?

Game trails where herds of animals walk are very road like as far as nature goes. I think getting a biological wheel to function would be the trick part. With the continuous turning nature of a wheel, how would the flesh rotate without ripping apart? If the meat wheel could rotate without tearing skin etc, then how would it be voluntarily powered by the animal? Unless it was just a passive system like a hoof, and the animal just rolled any direction the ground was sloped.
What is defined as a "road"? Are wheels completely useless in all situations without a predefined road of a certain material, thickness, length etc? Did the road have to come before the wheel?

They would need limbs anyway in order to push the wheels. and if the wheels can only get to predetermined locations then you would have to have reliably locatable sources of food over an evolutionary time span. and generally speaking in nature it's better to be able to do many things badly than one thing well. That's why omnivores are more resistant to Extinction, and why the dinosaurs with wings outlasted those that didn't.

People don't talk enough about how seemingly simple technologies have dependencies that make them more practical now than they would be by themselves in the past. As mention in the video, wheel is not much good without a road. And it's not just roads, but you also need good materials. A good wheel and axle should probably have iron or other hard/refined metal. Go back in history too far and you're trying to make everything out of wood, leather, stone, clay, etc, which is even less practical on uneven terrain. And if you think about it, you're probably going to have to power it with a work animal anyway, so why not just load your stuff directly on the animal?

It's interesting to think about the infrastructure required for just about everything around us. Like if you were to have a self sustaining Mars colony, think about the supply chain needed to get the base materials. Aluminum, glass, steel, semi-conductors, etc. On Earth we have a global network that produces these things. No one modern city could ever come close to providing that stuff by itself even on Earth. And on Mars there's no "off the grid" living. You either have full life support or your're dead.

The argument at the end doesn't really make sense. No one builds roads for free, the people building them get paid money. It is an area they have specialised in, and by doing it they receive adequate compensation for their time, so it is still ultimately a selfish thing. Without motivation from the selfish want of money, nothing would get built unless slaves were used. This works exactly the same way as making a dog do something it doesn't want to do by giving it treats, something we call 'training'. In other words, hypothetically if you could train an animal to build roads by trading their labour for food, then animals would build roads. This is no different to how our system/society/world works.

Government A wants to move supplies/people between place A and place B to encourage trade, growth and therefore stimulate their own coffers through taxes, manufacturing, trade and export etc. Gov A offers a contract to build said road, in which the contractee is recompensed through monetary gain, by extension so are their employees. The road gets built.

Government B also wants to move supplies/people between place A and place B, for the same reasons. Unlike Gov A they don't offer a contract which recompenses the builder of the road, expecting the road to be built at the buildees expense as they will see that it is going to be of great use to mankind. The road does not get built.

No matter how clever we get, we are all driven by basic, selfish animalistic instincts.

I can imagine an organic axle that supports an organic wheel. The axle would fit into the wheel's hub, which would be divided into an outgoing chamber for fresh blood, and an incoming chamber for blood to be returned to the body. Vessels within the (almost certainly bony!) wheel would provide for its feeding and waste removal.

Since the wheel would naturally be forcing the blood to its periphery, return vessels would need to be very muscular to force the depleted blood back to the central hub's receiving chamber, where the body would take over, providing some measure of suction to draw blood back into the body.

Is it biologically advantageous? In most Earth situations, not at all. But if this creature were living in something like our world's salt flats or a similar environment, perhaps?

I feel like spiders are the closest nature ever got to wheels and roads. If you look at how a spider runs, its legs almost "spin" around its body, so it keeps constant contact with the ground at all times even while moving fast. This let's spiders move really fast while also letting them go on almost any terrain.

And by roads I of course mean webs. They're little paths they make that only they can use, and they also have the benefit of being "selfish" (very rarely do spiders ever share a web), and also function as a source of food. Whats even cooler about spider legs is that they function like hydraulic pistons, almost like an engine. Except they use blood instead of water... which is just badass.

Seems to me that this explanation would still allow for natural wheels and roads among species that undergo kin selection, such as eusocial insects like bees. Species with multiple physiologically distinct castes (again, like eusocial insects) would be especially suited for this, since one or more castes could retain legs for the purpose of building new road systems more easily while a colony is still being established. Their exoskeletons also seem like a plausible starting point for the evolution of such a system, since chitin is strong, lightweight and easy (biologically) to work with, and could probably even evolve to be selectively mineralized (like the shells of some crustaceans) in the wheels for greater durability.

As for the benefit during the course of evolution, perhaps they evolved from small aquatic vortex feeders with small limbs inside the mouth with wheel-like structures on the end used to generate the aforementioned vortex to draw in food passively, but had to evolve a more active feeding mechanism due to changes in their local environment, leading to these limbs becoming externalized and used for propulsion, as well as the species gradually growing larger and more mobile. These limbs were coincidentally somewhat capable of traversing terrestrial environments similar to a wheeled vehicle, albeit not all that well, so they eventually evolved into some of the first partially (and later, fully) terrestrial animal life to feed on the at that time unexploited (and thus numerous) plant-like life on land. These limbs thus became more specialized for that purpose, and eventually they also adapted to save energy by reusing the tracks left by previous wheeled-organisms, eventually leading to the evolution of eusocial behavior and a colonial lifestyle.

I remember a teacher posed this question to me once, I was maybe 7th grade (like 14 years old), decades ago. I do not think it was a test of any kind, he just pondered on this subject. I then tried to come up with my belief that biologically it is very difficult if not impossible to make a wheel work. Today I happen to think the same thing as the main reason. Like you said, passing nutrients etc. would be very difficult, but also sealing the contact point (circle/cylinder?) between axle and wheel, and having a "bearing" to maintain the constant rolling friction, these are not what a biological system would be good at. And if the wheel should be powered, how the hell would biology accomplish that?! Therefore evolution never "tried" it. The road question is interesting, and one I have never really thought of, although a large enough wheel would need no roads :)

I don't really buy the importance of the road in this equation. If you've spent a while cruising the wilderness on an off road motorcycle or mountain bike, you'll know that animals absolutely do make trails that are smooth enough for wheels. These trails are emergent rather than engineered; the trail is made just by the movement of animals, who prefer to use it because it's easier. An automatic positive feedback loop. You can go FOREVER on these trails. They're actually dangerous because they let you go so far away from human-planned routes, VERY quickly. You can get lost in the spider web in minutes.

Or consider this. There exists such a thing as a motorcycle desert race. Point A has a start line, point B has someone waiting for you with a gas can, and in between is just the Mojave. Sand, brush, rocks, and wheeled vehicles hauling ASS across it. If you think you're going to get on the Interstate and get in front of them, you'd better have a good radar detector or be a fan of the back half of the pack.

Roads definitely are required if you want a biological Mercedes E350 sedan to evolve. But wheeled vehicles are pretty flexible, especially in regions with firmer and less obstructed ground like plains and deserts. I think the bigger problem is the irreducible complexity, AND the mechanical question of getting blood and nerves past an axle "bearing". Axles and bearings also require some good lubrication if it's going to last any time, let alone a lifetime. Then you need to come up with a kind of muscle that makes rotational motion rather than linear motion. Those problems mostly go away at cellular scale so I think that's why the bacterial flagellum is about as close as you get.

By the way, you don't need taxes to build roads. That's high-value infrastructure that people and businesses would willingly pay to make use of. RailROADs were the first big capital businesses as we know business today.

Michael: Why don't animals have wheels?
Me: I-

More foot/wheel surface area means more wearing out and more accidents and less likely to make an uphill climb since wheels cant provide any leverage against gravity (without arms that are strong enough to make wheels redundant) and the difficulty in stopping without increasing both energy needed for an organism and friction to the wheel to body contact wearing it down and nerves would either get knotted or be connected to independent brain like parts or not exist at all in the wheels. And how hard it would be to apply enough force to simply turn around and run from a predator. And enough mass to grab your food and pull it without turning the wheels which would require extra energy for breaking or reversing. Its mass would have to be centered always without arms limiting any reaching capabilities with arms too. Would have to maintain body temp to survive on dry land and not overheat or freeze. Easy to tangle wheels in webs. The amount of energy needed to accelerate increases exponentially (i think) at different masses making it impossible to hunt most things that move. Most might just die from finding a small decline in all directions and starving. Sex would be odd..

Another thing to think about is: If an animal had wheels instead of legs, they would still need a way to power those wheels. We would need a bone shaped like a crankshaft with a wheel attached to the center, and muscles attached on all sides of the offset. And a special ball joint on both ends of the bone. A spinning bone like this would also require a very specialized vascular system to provide circulation. Or the axle bone could grow to a certain size during infancy, then detach from the body's vascular system and cease growing.

fact is there are flat surfaces in nature.  the real reason is that wheels arent fixed to the body and cant be connected via circulatory, nervous, endocrine, musculature or any other body system.  i suppose an animal could evolve to use carotene for something like a wheel but there are just sooooo many reasons it doesnt happen..mainly linked to the above body system disconnection problem.

Is it possible that wheel-like structures were too good and caused species death due to overpopulation in early animals? The points in the video don't really make sense to me:

-Plenty of animals have some crazy traits which make no evolutionary sense of how they may have begun to come about and be selected for; Wheels seem easy enough

-Plenty of animals have trails and roads which wheels would make fine use of, as well as plenty of flat biomes available

Humans are technically all selfish--it's just we have pride mechanisms that allow us to push further through discomfort for notions of accomplishment; in other words, we do good things because we want to feel good about ourselves. We don't truly give a fuck what anyone else wants if it's not in some way for our own benefit--all other responses are fight and or flight psychological parameters for hard survival.

Nature develops incrementally--it cannot think ahead with a blueprint of what to build in advance like we can. Nature is blind and doesn't give a fuck--it uses pain and pleasure [motivation / 'reward(s)'] to get us to move, so that we can live long enough to reproduce--that's it. The natural state of stillness hurts like mother-f*cking-f*ck, because we are designed to be motivated, and not satisfied: it's why, even when under certain doom, no essential pain reliever will block out the horror--you will witness and experience whatever to unknown lengths and depths--simply because it is not advantageous or beneficial whether or not you die peacefully [as far as DNA operates]. Though, be sure to not', life is no essential protection from destruction--you cannot guarantee safety--to even try would mean fixing life itself. The Quartus Cursus (skater) is a small branch of the human family. They are most well known for their peculiar mode of transport, the 'skateboard' is a crudely fashioned board of wood with two wheels at each end. they can be found in most countries excluding India, and Japan. They are a mostly nomadic people, roaming from city to city scavenging for food at local fast food restaurants. Some of their favourite foods to eat include Burritos, McGang-Bangs, and is some cases pizza. They often gather at 'skate parks' for vulgar displays of power, or skill. Their seasonal mating locations, often called 'longboard race events' are where they gather in numbers ranging from anywhere between 10 to 100, and race down steep hills. Despite their speed and nimbility, they do have quite threatening natural enemies, the Abjectus Simplicius (retail Manager).

Saying that we are able to make roads because we are able to act in a non-selfish way is a bit of a stretch. We are able to abstract thought, and seeing how cooperation leads to greater long-term benefits than acting individually.
If another species did start making roads, whether predators or prey, other species would be able to recognize roads as evidence of their enemies. Herbivore roads would draw predators, and predator roads would drive away herbivores. So roads could only benefit either:
A) A migratory herbivore species at the top of the food chain, which does not fear any predators (such as Elephants, which do actually make & use roads in some areas)
B) A species which has already developed agriculture, and doesn't rely on hunting or gathering (such as humans. We don't mind if we scare away herbivores from roads & aren't worried about attracting predators)

I wouldn't agree with that selfish engineering. Is there anything that animal builds and it's used solely by its builder? Let's take dam made by beaver. It even creates new ecosystem for many animals. I suspect that theory would be correct in way "animals don't build something they won't use by themselves"... Or maybe no? That wouldn't be true, because animals build habitats for others just to eat them later or even eat their predators/victims. Of course access to the dam have to be defended, so other beavers won't take it. Same with road - it could serve others and it can be defended.

As of taxes - animals use them too. Not all cooperation within animal world is even. Often it's "we give you place to live, but you have to resign from something from you", i.e. relations with both mutualism and commensalism.

for a scifi writer's perspective, i would create something that necessitated or imitated roads first - maybe a burrowing creature smooths out the earth as it goes, maybe these creatures live among lava or ice floes, something like that.

then i'd consider where the wheeled creatures' wheels came from - i would assume something necessitated significant armour with hollow, nerve-less chambers, possibly something like a puffier armadillo or tortoise. then, over however many millenia of evolution, the hollowed chambers began to crack in the middle in a way that allowed them to rotate.

from there, a wheel that could be used on road-imitating surfaces could begin to develop, though all of these factors would imply to me that the creatures wouldn't live very long, generally speaking - the wheels will eventually wear down, and for something to evolve so unusually they'd most likely be a species with very large birth rates, which generally corresponds to shorter life spans in terrestrial creatures.

these factors would then imply that there would be a number of predators to feed on them - after all, when there's plentiful food, there'll be plentiful mouths to eat it. this could also drive evolution and create a distinct advantage in being able to move particularly quickly.

all in all, it COULD be justified, but it'll never be as practical as just walking without several other environmental factors to consider.

In Philip Pullman's book, the Amber Spyglass, a group of creatures called the Mulefa roll around on seed pods of trees. The seed pods drop from the trees and the Mulefa use them to roll around. This weakens the seed pods which allows them to split open and scatter seeds for more trees to grow. It's a symbiotic relationship. Without the trees, the Mulefa wouldn't have wheels to get around and without the Mulefa, the trees wouldn't be able to crack open their pods and reproduce. As for roads, they are merely streams of lava from volcanoes which cooled into a flat tar like substance.

I'm reminded of the book The Amber Spyglass by Phillip Pullman (third in the trilogy that starts with The Golden Compass). In the book, in a parallel universe, there exists a race called the mulefa. They're described as looking like a mix between elephants and antelopes, but with their limbs in a diamond shape instead of a rectangle shape, and they ride around on wheels. All across the terrain of this world are smooth "roads" made of volcanic rock, and immensely tall trees that bear hard flat circular seed pods. The mulefa's front and back legs have a single curved claw, which they put through the softer center of the seed pods. So the seed pod is the wheel and the claw is the axle.  The book describes the relationship between the mulefa and the trees as being symbiotic: riding on the seed pod wheels wears them down and causes them to crack open, which is the only way to release the seeds so they can be planted. In return, the oil from the center of the seed pods is absorbed into the mulefa's bodies through the claw and increases their intelligence.

I think the problem with roads and wheels from a natural perspective is not the idea of other animals using the roads. In fact quite the opposite, other animals using the roads you make could provide a serious advantage in the sense that those animals would likely shift to not eating you in the hopes that you would make more roads as we have seen in many other symbiotic relationships. (crocodiles and birds, for instance) I would posit that the issue here is simply return on investment. A giraffe growing a slightly longer neck is not a huge leap in terms of the required resources it takes for the giraffe to survive. On the other hand, building the biological tools to make a semi-smooth road and then maintain it while also ensuring that whatever is on the other end of that road is worth all the effort is very challenging and requires specific circumstances to even be useful.

Let's make the assumption that an animal suddenly evolved the tools to build a mile long road within the span of a week and could maintain said road using 25% of the time it spends awake. Even assuming that the animal has already constructed the road and recouped the resources/energy used in doing so, what could be along this road that would radically improve the animals overall lifestyle? The only circumstance I can think of is connecting a reliable and good source of water that is not a good source of food (rare in and of itself) to an area that is conversely lacking water but a rich source of food. (perhaps even rarer) This does not even take into account that the wheel would likely get in the way of hunting off of the road which means it almost certainly would only work for an herbivore. So now we have an herbivore that has an extremely predictable lifestyle which is easy to find and can only flee or chase along a set path that is easy to follow and finite in length. Does this sound like a successful animal to you? It doesn't to me.

And as a side note, in a way ants and bees have taxes. Bees even practice what could be called a form of democracy when selecting a new location for a hive.

The notion that the difference is selfish v. cooperative is a bit romantic and not entirely realistic.

Humans are selfish, we're just more capable of long-term thinking than animals (not that the average human doesn't have a long way to go on this one), as well as predicting the likely behavior of others. Our ancestors who built roads could grasp that if they built a road, guarded it (or had the government enforce property rights since that is more reliable and efficient), and demanded valuable goods or even money then people would give it to them. Similarly we can grasp that a government which helps promote these projects through taxation can 1. Prevent us from having to pay to go down roads. And 2. Lead to more roads and more commerce from those roads and from not having to pay a toll. Due to tragedy of the commons the marketplace can not always do things which are beneficial, even though the marketplace is generally a good way of distributing goods and services, hence people dreaming of more money or for the more long-sighted among us better health, better science and technology, the wonder of the knowledge we will learn and achievements that will be had tomorrow it makes sense to support taxation to fund infrastructure as well as numerous other things such as healthcare, NASA (the benefits could be huge if we would adequately fund NASA), and of course addressing climate change.

Short-termism is the greatest problem human beings have, much moreso than selfishness (which isn't even a problem when it's truly long-term since then it nearly dovetails with humanity's common interests). We may be better at long-term thinking than animals but we need to be even better. "Living in the moment" is for the birds and the bees, the best thing to do is prepare for the future and be mindful of what is going on in the world especially what's going on in politics.

The long necks are most likely advantageous in physical competition with other males for mating rights.

The wheel isn't really an example of selflessness. (such psychological trait could have never evolved). Collecting taxes from other people by the king/ruler for him to spend is perfectly sensible and requires no selflessness. Investing that money in roads so that more merchants can be taxed and the military can be moved more effectively is again perfectly sensible. If roads help other people that's just an unintended consequence.

On the other hand appearing selfless for social creatures is important as they will rely on other people paying back the kindness at one point, but even that's not selflessness, simply an unstated business transaction.

A giraffe doesn't have a long neck for food advantages...  It's been observed that they eat the majority of their food at or below shoulder height. Their necks are more likely a result of the tactical advantage in the male's mating battles. They battle by bashing heads together like a ram, but with out the running start. The longer the neck the greater the force of their blows, and better mating success. As this trait is heritable, longer necks will develop over time. It's also worth noting, that the animals with the longest necks have the highest mortality rates in severe droughts. Though more research is needed on this, it's hypothesized that the energy requirements are just enough that they aren't able to compete in these conditions, making the mating theory more plausible to me...

A wheel requires more material to elevate oneself from the ground adequately than legs do. Save energy on wheels, expend energy on larger form? A bit of a pain in the ass. Plus with that small amount of surface area to volume, it'd be hard to keep warm and expensive to regenerate.

Mostly though, I would lean towards the fact that having 2 legs lets you do ALMOST what wheels can do. There are tradeoffs for each, surely, but the way a leg moves, it takes half of its cycle going forwards, and half of it going back. When it contacts the ground, it combines a small "Arc" of pushing force, not unlike spinning part of a wheel, and a bit of pushing force away from the ground, like a small jump. With legs in even sets, one can keep one leg "rotating" forward at all times, and the rewind time of the reversing motion doesn't matter as much.

The only reasons why humans enjoy wheels so much is because we don't have to feed them, fix them, or consistently grow such a precise show. Make one, last a long while, hell, one wheel can make a job easier on its own, vs 2 legs.

But if you're alive and you're already handling complex crap all the time? Might as well just have control over all the bits inbetween, and achieve force needed to propel yourself simultaneously. In fact, much our biology's shape is multitasking, I would ask one to counter-ponder.

To be fair when discussing roads and the idea of not being able to defend them that's only partly true. The infrastructure of a society is generally only built within its defensible borders. For instance Rome paved roads for its soldiers but it didn't go out of its way to pave roads where it hadn't already established some hegemony or perhaps sought to.

Furthermore there are plenty of animals that cooperate and create infrastructure to do so, ants being perhaps the best example. Ants are basically pure communism and they also have the capacity for an astonishing number of human-like behaviors such as deception or slavery. They also totally do war, obviously.

I'd be really curious to see if there were ever any historical basis for humans going of their way to create infrastructure that wasn't selfish. Human tribal behavior evolving into societies merely extends the framework of cooperation beyond the scope of what any animal can do due to communication and sophisticated language and self awareness.

So while I enjoy this video I'm not entirely sure the conclusion is totally satisfying. Seems more like one of those things that makes less sense the more you think about it. Then again I haven't read the Dawkins essay so I am probably missing some more context.

I might be wrong, but I feel have explanations given for the three phenomena discussed are false.

1. Wheels: Some traits develop just to better attract opposite sex like peacock's feathers (sexual selection), though they might not serve any purpose at all. The main reason they didn't develop is because a wheel requires independent rotation on an axis without being bound by any object. As with any other organ/limb to develop, wheels would require constant nutrition and protection i.e., connection to main body through blood vessels, lymphatic system, skeletal, muscular etc..while would make rotation impossible.

2. Roads: Many kinds of ants have been shown to make roads for miles and miles within a forest. Just the path they continuously walk becomes a road and each ant hill can have several roads extending in different directions like superhighways jutting out of a city.

3. Taxes: This can easily be summed as a form of altruistic behavior, though at a much larger scale. We pay taxes so that other people both in present and future including our own children will take advantage of the added benefits these taxes will bring about including research, commerce, security through military, healthcare etc.. And examples for altruistic behaviour are aplenty.

Isn't a "game trail" a road? Not perfectly smooth, but neither were early roads. (Or modern ones here in the U.S. Snow belt.) I feel it's the axle. That's what I was thinking. Many animals make game trails and even more use them; including us.

I don't even believe in evolution, but 70 percent of the world is covered in water, and evolutionists believe land animals emerged from the sea. A wheel, and a road, would not be useful underwater, and wheels don't really work on sand or mud, which is what surrounds most bodies of water.

Also, roads are usually fundamentally selfish. The Romans were the first to really utilize the concept, and they built them initially for military movement. Roads made it easier to amass troops to a central place, and to resupply them. Most people at the time didn't have wheeled vehicles, so they weren't being used by other people. Even in America, the interstate system was built by Eisenhower to make it easier to send equipment and resources from one side of the country to the other in case of a Soviet attack. If you actually look at where the interstates travel, most travel near various locations of military outposts and major cities, because that was where they were needed the most for defense.

Also, many animals make trails, most notably ants, which use them for efficient transport. Army ants are most famous for this hauling large amounts of prey along their trails after an attack. Humans also started with trails, and as you stated rails preceded roads in many places. Rails started in mines, as a more efficient means of transporting ore and debris, and were entirely selfish not being used by others. The railway system was not needed until locomotives were built, which proves the wheel can precede the road or rail. Same with most modern roads, having been built for the purpose of automobiles.

It could also be about conservation of energy.  Nothing in nature wastes energy, its all very efficient. All systems feed into other systems in one way or another and vice versa.  And a wheel doesn't conserve or give back any energy.  The kinetic energy created by the wheel spinning and the energy created from friction from the wheel rubbing against the ground doesn't go back into any system.  Its just raw energy that is absorbed into the ground as heat, or into the air as heat and is never used by anything really.  Only humans could create something that wastes a bunch of energy and be so arrogant to ask nature, "why didn't you think of this?"

I see the wheel more like a early evidence of the fact that we are social animals that change the environment to suit us than the fact that we are unselfish... the beaver will not avoid building a damn because salmon will benefit from it, it will just do what it takes for him to survive... As much as we invented roads to improve transportation between our "colonies" and allow our groups to survive better.

Also I think there is a problem with the concept of evolution when you take it to a question like why animals don't have whells? evolution is not a magical process where  the best thing possible happens, it's a process where the mutation that allows an organism to survive better in a given environment -  that's why different animals have different ways to deal with cold climates.

Since i seem to be the first making that link, i want to point you to the works of the Author Philip Pullmann, namely "The Amber Spyglass." It is a fantasy book where a race of animals in another world has evolved to use wheels as their main mode of movement. The wheels are not part of their body but are the seed-pods of trees that take roughly the shape of wheels and are coated in oil to allow frictionless movement, thus eliminating the problem of moving parts on the same body. This relationship between animal and tree is mutually beneficial, because the seed-pods crack open after a while and help to spread the seeds of the tree. The world that these creatures live in on the other hand is covered by road-like natural structures that (if i remember correctly) formed out of cooled lava and are smooth enough for the creatures to ride on extremely fast. These special conditions of their world made a successful evolution in this particular direction possible and beneficial.
I just wanted to point to that (of course highly hypothetical) example of animals on wheels in literature because i personally like how the author explains their existence with evolutionary principles.

For reference:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Races_and_creatures_in_His_Dark_Materials#Mulefa

From a growth perspective the wheel is not simple.

How do you grow something that can free spin without detaching it from yourself to become a separated physical object?

In nature there are no "two part" animals. For an animal to have a wheel that can free spin, it would need to grow it and than attach it back onto itself in a way that lets it spin freely.

In an abstract way you could say humans have wheels. From a developmental point of view we solved the problem of free spinning by not growing it as part of our own body but instead molded it from our environment and made it part of our optional tools that can be  used to extend our physical presence in the world.

By contrast the closest thing you will find that is physically part of a body are socket joints (which can't free spin) and the gears in some insects legs:
http://www.insidescience.org/content/insect-jumps-powered-mechanical-gears/1390

But again, these "wind up" in one direction and than return the other way, they cant free spin without ripping themselves from the attachment point of the body they are a part of.

Regarding animals not building roads because "roads aren't selfish enough".

That's not entirely true.  I work out in the bush which is criss-crossed with game trails that are formed by larger animals (ungulates, bears, wolves, etc...).  These are essentially animal highways since, like humans, most animals would rather walk along an easy path that's relatively clear than walk through the thick undergrowth.  These trails become better and better simply by virtue of having a steady stream of large animals walking them, breaking branches along the way and disturbing the soil to such a degree that it's impossible for any obstacles in the form of vegetation growing along the path.  And of course, the animals are all acting selfishly since they're just looking for the path of least resistance.  If you were to try going along these trails with a mountain bike, you'd probably be pretty pleased.

Of course, animals also walk through the undergrowth and have to forge new paths for a variety of reasons, so wheels wouldn't be sufficient.  Still, in theory, if evolution could create the wheel, a niche for such an animal could exist along these game trails.  This hypothetical wheeled animal could simply make use of existing trails and also help maintain these trails by using them.

I was really interested by this issue not long ago and I must say that there's an aspect of wheeled animals that this video didn't cover. First off, roads aren't absolutely necessary for such animals to exist. There's a lot of flat surfaces that they can use to wheel around, dried lake beds for example. The problem with these surfaces is that if our creatures have no ability to control their movements, like tumbleweed that totally depends on wind, it wouldn't be a profitable evolutionary strategy because of the windrose which results in the log run in some kind of a drifting of all wheeled community to some corner of that lakebed where it would die out. But there's actually a kind of the wheel that nature could invent to make some animals evolutionary successful. Let's imagine some turtles who would shed their shell like snakes who shed their skin. Shellless "turtles" are helpless and could be easily eaten up so they would have to stay in their old shells until a new one has fully formed. Some of them would find out that they can use these shells to move around while being totally safe. And these hypothetical creatures would thrive if there would be some large flat lakebed around. But there weren't any animals like these. Why?

Here's a speculation on how to evolve a wheeled animal (an alien like this was actually described in the book "Barlowe's Guide to the Extraterrestrials" ):
Take an aquatic creature that can produce pearl-like secretions around grains of sand. As sea levels fluctuate or other evolutionary pressures push it into dry land, it grows these secretions to spheres big enough to support its weight and roll around on. I know, it's not exactly a wheel, but it solves the problems of an axle or gear differentials, and the organism can still secrete stuff to grow/maintain the sphere.
Now for "selfish" roads: in relatively flat terrain, on the seashore or river valley, these rollers may have limited mobility, but enough to flatten the terrain with repeated use, wearing ruts that become proto- roads. What are they going after? Best bet for survival is to be omnivorous, like bears. They can bushwhack through vegetation for the stuff they like, occasionally flushing out live prey to catch, and pooping out the seeds along the roadside. Soon the vegetation growing alongside the road is skewed towards what the rollers eat. More rollers come and expand the road, encouraging spread of seeds and migration of prey animals who have easier transportation and abundant food along the way. Now the rollers have "speed traps"
along their highways, running down the prey animals, or set up snares to lure them (think of Wile E. Coyote setting up free birdseed for the Road Runner).
Repeat this process over evolutionary time, and you can have a system of roads criss-crossing, overlapping, competing, altering the planetary landscape and encouraging the spread of numerous other species, with the rollers as maintenance crew and toll collectors. If you saw it from space, you might think it the work if an intelligent species. But none if this would require a level of intelligence beyond giant beavers building dams and clearing woodlands (these actually existed during the Ice Ages, I think).

Why do insects have wings?
Well we can all think of the advantages being able to fly offers.
But where did wings come from?
If we go back in time to the proto-insect there were no wings. Their exoskeletons made them kind of like a modern day tank. What evolutionary force compelled the ancestors of flying insects to abandon the protection of a solid carapace in favor of a wing?
We don't know.
What we do know is that wings didn't happen over night. There were millions and millions of years of evolution needed to alter the exoskeleton from a solid form of armor into a structure that enabled flight.
So for millions and millions of years the ancestors of flying insects were in the process of losing the advantage of armor while the loss of that protection was not replaced by the eventual benefit of flight.
Generation after generation selectively bred for the loss of exoskeleton protection while generation after generation accrued subtle changes that would eventually produce a wing.
It seems counter intuitive, doesn't it?

From what I have read, they do seem to be significantly more likely to produce fertile offspring compared to the mule, which has almost zero chance of being fertile.  The differing number of chromosomes can probably be worked around to some extent by careful breeding.

Part of the issue here is that "species" is not a precise term; it can be difficult to say whether some set of creatures are a separate species since there is continuous variation.  Look-up "ring species" for example.  Wikipedia has a short article on canid hybrids ("Canid hybrid").  Coyotes still have the same number of chromosomes as dogs/wolves.  Jackals do not, so a dog/jackal hybrid is similar to a donkey/horse hybrid (a mule); the hybrid animal is usually infertile.

This is more of a semantic argument.  Evolution is usually used to mean "evolution by natural selection".  Deliberate selective breading of dogs by man is generally not taken to be "natural selection".  Such selective breading can cause change much quicker than natural selection.  Natural selection generally works on very small differences in survival/reproduction rates over a long time.  With selective breading, we can pick a specific feature, and only bread animals with that feature.

Where did you get this "2%" figure from?  All mammals (including humans) share significantly more than 2% dna (more like 90% for protein coding sequences).  Dogs and wolves are considered sub-species of one species, so not "completely different animals".  I have know people with "dogs" which are a quarter wolf (they are dangerous to keep as pets), so they can breed together.

This is not what "Theory" means.
Let me break it down for you.
Facts are Data, an Observation. So if I use Gravity as an Example, the "Fact of Gravity" is dropping an egg on the ground, and watching that happen
Laws are Descriptions, normally in the form of Equations, the "Law of Gravity" is describing how fast that egg falls on the way, and how much force it takes to break it (9.8 m/s/s)
The "Theory of Gravity" is Einstein's General Relativity.
So Both Gravity and Evolution are All Three =^_^=

I was going to involve myself in this debate about evolution, but then I remembered the old commenting protocol, D.O.N.T which stands for don't.

So, if I see a bullet in flight and I can slow down time and watch the bullet's path, I can measure the path and trace it back.  If I find a gun along that path it is logical to conclude that that bullet came from that gun.  If I then check the gun and see that the caliber matches, that the muzzle is hot and the angle of the gun says that the kick has lifted the barrel I am not assuming the bullet came from the gun, I am drawing a logical, evidence based, conclusion.

You don't know how evolution works. Only if a series of favorable genetic changes occur and those mutated animals live to reproduce and populate will any trait come to being. Humans got really lucky.

Modern Humans originated in hot, dry regions. Here, the ability to find, remember, and communicate the location of water- requiring advanced brains- was a big edge in the survival game and so was selected for.

Brains use a whole lot of energy to operate, so generally speaking unless the increased mental capacity allows you to find a great deal more food than other animals with lower mental capacity, it is not selected for.

However, consider it this way- perhaps we are not the only species to develop advanced mental capacity, but simply the first on our planet. From our perspective, we are the only ones with advanced brain- but this doesn't mean no other advanced species will ever evolve.

Hi, wings originally developed as membranes under the arm of reptile animals. At first the membranes would just help the reptile to glide a little bit - this was probably most useful to reptiles that lived in trees or on large rocks. If you think about it, legs are actually a kind of next-step-up (no pun intended) from wheels. Like a wheel, the bit that contacts the ground stays put, then moves up, moves forward at twice the rate of the load, moves down, then stops again. The difference being you can change the "shape" of the "wheel" simply by altering the path your foot takes before it reaches the ground again. Machine wheels don't have that capability, and can even lose out in traction by their fixed shape.

The reason why animals don't have wheels has a more negative effect. Since evolution needs to take place over several generations, an intermediate wheel-foot appendage, for example some sort of many sided polygon, would in fact hinder rather than help the animal. Such disadvantage would cause the intermediary to die out before passing on the wheel gene/allele, causing evolution of the wheel appendage to stop prematurely.

Ah, but the difference is the fact that goats don't make roads intentionally. They take the same path over and over because it's the easiest way up or down a mountain. The fact that a road forms is completely incidental.

Though there are other animals that build such roads. Ants. Why ants don't use wheels is a nice question:) The existence of roads in their everyday life combined with their expertise in labor distribution (f.e. warriors- workers) would allow such an wheelvolution(f.e. a sub-category of workers, wheely-carriers:P). But as mentioned in the video, wheel it's not a viable solution for nature.:)

But a goat isn't thinking about the road he's making, he just take the best path to his objective (food maybe :P). So he's not "making a road" and using it over and over again, he just takes the best route and then repeats over and over because it's better for him. 
A lot of animals do that to, in the savanas, forests and other places the animals make tracks, even us, humans; that's because it's not a road, it's just a easier route used by everyone with intelligence to do it. :)

Goats don't "build" roads. There is a species of... I think it's a mouse-like organism that clears and smoothes road-like trails through the underbrush by running them daily and pushing away any debris.

Defining what is, and what isn't a road can be tricky though. 

For instance; Any animal has a tendency to optimize their travel route (save energy, avoid predators, etc). In modern human society this can be seen through urban pathfinding. In animal society (?) this would be evident around the watering hole too. In both cases, the terrain is eroded away to create a stable path. Not only is the path gradually formed, but through favoritism, is is formed more rapidly.

To summarise: Plausible ideas surrounding a phenomenon are called "Hypotheses". Should a hypotheses survive years of meticulous testing and counters, it is regarded as "fact" or "Scientific theory" until observations disprove it. That is what evolution and gravity and relativity is. "Scientific Laws", on the other hand, are the observations; such as v=u+at, V=IR or E=Mc^2. You'd be stealing a persons intelligence if you didn't teach them current scientific theories, like evolution.

No respectable observations have ever disagreed with Darwin's Hypothesis, hence why it is now regarded as scientific fact (AKA Scientific Theory). Your free to have a shot at disproving Evolution, mind, but make sure you attack it from all angles or your observations will be disregarded at flawed. The greatest biologists of the past 200 years have failed to do it but that doesn't mean you can't try.

A "scientific theory" is a collection of facts which explains a phenomenon, otherwise known as a hypothesis, which stands up to repeated critique via the scientific method. That's all it is. It's fact, just by a different name, until such a time where observation disagrees with it and it becomes known that it was never fact to begin with.

Correction to the giraffe part: giraffes necks' main purpose is not so they can reach higher into trees and obtain more food. Their necks are actually used for sexual selection. Males use their long necks to fight off other male giraffes (the longer necks are more advantageous in this situation, so females tend to mate with the longer necks). This is proven because females actually have shorter necks than males on average. And plus, they prefer eating at just about shoulder height.

"whats up with everyone treating this theory of evolution as a fact?"

Evolution is both fact AND theory, a fact being a verifiable objective observation, with the theory then explaining that fact. Gravity is both fact and theory too- gravity is a fact, explaining gravity is the theory.

Actually, giraffes don't have long necks to get more food. It was found that giraffes don't use their necks more often in higher places for food than lower places. Giraffes have evolved to have longer necks because of courtship battles. Courtship battles are an example of sexual selection. Those with longer necks will be more successful in courtship battles for a mate. This is an example of the process of evolution by natural selection, but was not influenced by location of food sources.

There is not such thing as Scientific fact. Everything can be disproven, and everything can change in science. If someone proves something wrong, it may not be excepted at first until further studies and tests, but if it disproves a previous theory (or it's synonym in SCIENCE, fact) then the more correct theory is accepted. Science doesn't keep itself down by claiming anything is 100% true because someone else may be more right about a topic.

If you claim that we can see/tough/smell/taste/hear God then why can he not be detected by scientific experimentation? If this god can be perceived by the senses, then he surely can be detectable and provable... yet this is not the case. Popularity does not equal validity. Many people believe in a deity (or even multiple deities) because of culture, indoctrination, and ignorance. For many reasons, people use the concept of God to fill gaps of what they do not know. But that isn't evidence.

Theory - An idea or concept that has yet to be proved. (Eg. Aliens)
SCIENTIFIC theory - An idea or concept that has been proved using current methods and is accepted by the scientific community as true, until proven otherwise. (Eg. Gravity/Evolution.)

To answer your first post: YouTube starts caching the video page when it starts receiving a large amount of views within a short timespan - to avoid too much stress on their servers. Flagella in bacteria and eukaryote sperm cells are micro rotary engines, but not used as wheels per se because wheels make less sense at that scale where pretty much every thing can be considered to be a swimmer. The ATP synthase molecule is also a little rotary nano-electric motor which rams phosphates on to ADP, but not a wheel.

On the macro scale of course, wheels had no evolutionary pressure whereas legs and limbs absolutely did. Even stubby fins or legs can help a critter out.
